title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, known as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," amends the definitions of law enforcement officers in the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, titled the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," modifies the definitions of law enforcement officers in retirement systems to include Assistant United States Attorneys. Paragraph (17) of section 8401 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include Assistant United States Attorneys. The effective date of the Act and its amendments is the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. The term "incumbent" refers to an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of the Act. The Department of Justice must notify these individuals of their election rights within 6 months. Incumbents can choose to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election will be treated as an election under the Act. Failure to timely elect under this subsection will be treated as an election made on the last allowable day. The election must be made before the 90th day after receiving notice or the incumbent separates from service. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until an election is made. Incumbents who elect the option will have their service treated accordingly. The option to elect retirement coverage as an Assistant United States Attorney will result in service being treated according to specific provisions of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice must make additional payments to the Office of Personnel Management for makeup contributions. The Office of Personnel Management requires additional payments for makeup contributions from the Department of Justice, which will be deposited into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. This includes individual and Government contributions for Assistant United States Attorneys before the effective date of their election, plus interest. No individual liability is created for any contribution shortfalls. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for the Act, including determining interest on required contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
